title: 114_hr2669
content: The Act may be cited as the "Anti-Spoofing Act of 2016" and includes provisions for spoofing prevention. The "Anti-Spoofing Act of 2016" includes provisions for preventing misleading or inaccurate caller identification information, expanding coverage to text messages and voice services. The "Anti-Spoofing Act of 2016" expands coverage to text messages by defining a text message as a message consisting of text, images, sounds, or other information transmitted to or from a device identified by a 10-digit telephone number or N11 service code. The "Anti-Spoofing Act of 2016" defines a text messaging service as a service that enables the transmission or receipt of text messages, including SMS and MMS, but excludes real-time voice or video communication. The "Anti-Spoofing Act of 2016" defines a text messaging service as a service that enables the transmission or receipt of text messages, including SMS and MMS, but excludes real-time voice or video communication. Additionally, the Act defines voice service as any service interconnected with the public switched telephone network that provides voice communications to an end user using resources from the North American Numbering Plan. The Communications Act of 1934 is being amended to address misleading or inaccurate information in telephone facsimile transmissions. The Commission is required to implement regulations within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission must develop consumer education materials within 1 year of the Act's enactment to help consumers identify scams using misleading caller information. The Commission will develop consumer education materials to help consumers protect against scams using misleading caller information by identifying existing technologies and providing details on how to access and use them. The Commission will develop consumer education materials to help consumers identify and avoid scams using misleading caller information, including providing information on technologies and updates on a regular basis. The materials will be included on the Commission's website. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on actions taken to combat fraudulent caller identification information. The Federal Trade Commission is taking action against fraudulent caller identification information by examining trends in scams, enforcement actions, and industry efforts to develop standards. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 18 months on developing technical standards to combat fraudulent caller identification information and recommending additional actions to address this issue. The report to Congress will include findings and recommendations on combating fraudulent caller identification information. This section does not affect rules related to the Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 or the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. The term "Commission" refers to the Federal Communications Commission. The House of Representatives passed the document on November 14, 2016. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
